channel.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
channel.description: I didnt deob it yet, athough i decompiled it and saw NO static member scrambling, theres 2 nice new openGL stub classes and theres probaly more ill see when ive deobbed it

I didnt deob it yet, athough i decompiled it and saw NO static member scrambling, theres 2 nice new openGL stub classes and theres probaly more ill see when ive deobbed it

I deobbed it and so have several other people. Notably Semaphore, who sent me a deob originally. I understand you think you know what you’re talking about, but you don’t. You’re wrong.

Read full topic

@frank wrote:

Object blah = ...; while (true) { Object blah2 = dostuff(blah); if (blah.equals(blah2)) { break; } blah = blah2; }not recursion, but still simple

item.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:37, topic:299645”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=395949.msg2951354#msg2951354 date=1252531953]
I’ve read through code with loops that by definition only execute once in at least the 508 and 525 version, I can find it if you wish.
[/quote]

Please do, I’d be interested in seeing how they work. BTW, once you inline constants, simple predicate expressions like that if’s predicate should be easy to evaluate. Once it does, a deobfuscator could simply re-work the flow so that it is different. I’d like to thank frank_ for making me think about how to remove dummy args which led to me thinking about inlining constants. Well tbh, thanks to frank_ for telling me how he would go about them, and I, being a noob, did not understand wtf he was talking about and thought about it on my own.[/quote]

It used to be as simple as inlining constants, but they aren’t strict constants like they used to be in past obfuscations either. They are accessed and set in other operations that don’t matter either. The cleanest way I thought about handling them is to keep applying the same ‘inline constants, remove constant operations’ to the whole codebase over and over again until it doesn’t fix anything else, then all of the bad stuff should have been removed. Certainly not the fastest or most elegant way, but it would be simple, which might turn out to be better in the long run. (like when (not if) they change the obfuscation)

Read full topic

item.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I’ve read through code with loops that by definition only execute once in at least the 508 and 525 version, I can find it if you wish.

Please do, I’d be interested in seeing how they work. BTW, once you inline constants, simple predicate expressions like that if’s predicate should be easy to evaluate. Once it does, a deobfuscator could simply re-work the flow so that it is different. I’d like to thank frank_ for making me think about how to remove dummy args which led to me thinking about inlining constants. Well tbh, thanks to frank_ for telling me how he would go about them, and I, being a noob, did not understand wtf he was talking about and thought about it on my own.

Read full topic

item.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:32, topic:299645”][quote author=qauters link=topic=395949.msg2949921#msg2949921 date=1252441338]
Hmm, control-flow is pretty decently deobfuscated well it has weird things here and there but that’s also the fault of the decompilers
[/quote]
are you saying code such as

if (i != 1) { if (i != 2) { if (i != 3) { ... } ... return; } ... return; } ... return;
is acceptable?

if so, get the fuck out of my house[/quote]
That’s what the decompiler does, not me -.-. I’m not going to rewrite all the code just for the fun of it -.-. Deobs are used to quickly lookup shit, which it can be used for.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:34, topic:299645”]I was talking about code such as:

while(true){
doSomething();
if(someDummyArg == -876)
     break;
}

That could be simplified to:

doSomething();

It makes looking for patterns a huge pain, and is painful on the eyes to read.[/quote]
Don’t think it adds while true loops to break out with dummy arguments, but the dummy arguments itself are fucked up yea.
Although it doesn’t matter to badly for patterns if done properly. Removing it however is a pain in the ass, since you need to recursively check multiple methods to track down the dummy arguments. But since this is a basic deob, I can’t be bothered -.-. The worst part in it is that popcorn’s deobber doesn’t simplify shits and doesn’t fix IXOR’s which are way more annoying ((~i == -15) or incase of jode (i ^ 0xFFFFFFFF) == -15).

Read full topic

item.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I was talking about code such as:

while(true){
doSomething();
if(someDummyArg == -876)
     break;
}

That could be simplified to:

doSomething();

It makes looking for patterns a huge pain, and is painful on the eyes to read.

Read full topic

item.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Mopman:

basically. and to be clear, that wasn’t some kind of diss at quarters releasing the one he did, it was just in response to “why would anyone want a new deobber” or w/e

Well people asked for new deobber, saying popcorn’s was broken. So that’s why I released this deob to prove it still works.

Moparisthebest:

I think what Mopman is referring to is that the deob still has heavy control-flow obfuscation, and that combined with all of the nasty shifts and other forms make it hardly human readable. Where as the 3XX version deobs were at least understandable to the human eye.

Hmm, control-flow is pretty decently deobfuscated well it has weird things here and there but that’s also the fault of the decompilers
Other forms of deobfuscation are indeed not done, but well it’s popcorn’s deobber I just gave that result

Well you can’t compare 3XX to 5XX considering it’s way more obfuscated, well you can remove ixor/simplify shifts though.

Read full topic

item.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“light232, post:24, topic:299645”][quote author=qauters link=topic=395949.msg2949506#msg2949506 date=1252411517]

But it isn’t deobbed

I mean, it compiles, that’s a plus point I guess…

It is deobfuscated -.-, well it fixes the control flow which is basically all current public deobs ever had…

ownagesbot:
Ofcourse I know what it is, obfuscation secures the code making it unreadable and preferable uncompileable. Some forms of obfuscation used by Jagex: Control flow obfuscation, increasing shift sizes, inverting expressions using IXOR, adding random variables, adding random unused code, static member randomalization, name randomalization etc

What this deob has solved is the control flow obfuscation and renames to a bit more readable names. Just like any other deob ever made using popcorn’s deobber. My own deobfuscater (built in my updater) also has the ability to remove IXOR and simplifies shifts which is useful when updating, but that doesn’t rename etc and doesn’t remove problematic exception throws therefor it’s uncompilable if decompiled by any current decompiler. Although it produces way clearer results then the official code.

Now tell me again, why is this not a deob -.-
[/quote]
if its uncompileable then whats the point of obfuscating it[/quote]
It deobfuscates for updating -.- as I said before, it’s way easier to create your updater if the ixor inversions are gone and shifts are the way they should. The deob released is compilable.

Read full topic

Now tell me again, why is this not a deob -.-[/quote]

ownagesbot:
Ofcourse I know what it is, obfuscation secures the code making it unreadable and preferable uncompileable. Some forms of obfuscation used by Jagex: Control flow obfuscation, increasing shift sizes, inverting expressions using IXOR, adding random variables, adding random unused code, static member randomalization, name randomalization etc

What this deob has solved is the control flow obfuscation and renames to a bit more readable names. Just like any other deob ever made using popcorn’s deobber. My own deobfuscater (built in my updater) also has the ability to remove IXOR and simplifies shifts which is useful when updating, but that doesn’t rename etc and doesn’t remove problematic exception throws therefor it’s uncompilable if decompiled by any current decompiler. item.title: RuneTEK 5, bad obfuscation
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:20, topic:299645”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=395949.msg2948196#msg2948196 date=1252340287]
And you consider that a decent deob, do you?
[/quote]
It’s a decent deob yes , just a decent as any deob from popcorn’s deobber this far.
It works without crashing, without problems. The way of deobbing isn’t decent, but works :P[/quote]Do you know what the words ‘obfuscate’ and ‘deobfuscate’ mean? They differ completely from them of ‘compile’ and ‘decompile’.

Read full topic
